msDesc.head: A composite manuscript book including poetic anthologies (Parts B, F, G, H and I), as well as theological and pastoral texts. The volume includes poems by Hildebert of Lavardin, Marbod of Rennes and Bernard Silvestris as well as the Song of Songs, and texts by Anselm and Martin of Braga. Some similarities in script, mise-en-page and decoration between Parts B, F, G, H and I suggest a common origin (possibly a common scribe) for the poetic anthologies.

physDesc.p: Composite manuscript: fols. 1–26 || fols. 27–57 || fols. 58-69 || fols. 70-83 || fols. 84-93 || fols. 94-109 || fols. 110-116 || fols. 117-123 || fols. 124-133

supportDesc.extent: iv (paper fly leaves) + 134 leaves + ii (paper fly leaves)
supportDesc.foliation: Foliation in pencil. The first parchment leaf is blank and foliated as (v). The two final paper fly leaves are foliated 134 and 135.

binding.p: Seventeenth-century laced-case limp parchment binding. The spine is now partly loose; medieval sewing supports are visible.

history.provenance: William Laud (1573–1645). Inscribed, ‘Liber Guilielmi Laud Archiepiscopi Cantuarij et Cancellarij Vniuersitatis Oxoniensis 1634’ (fol. 1r, lower margin).
history.acquisition: Bodleian Library: first donation from Laud, 22 May 1635 (R. W. Hunt (ed.), A Summary Catalogue of Western Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library at Oxford, vol. 1 (Oxford, 1953), p. 129-130).

Former shelfmark ‘C.2’ (fol. (i) verso and fol. (iv) verso). In 1641, the Laudian MSS were arranged in eleven compartments, lettered A-L: see F. Madan and H. H. E. Craster (ed.), A Summary Catalogue of Western Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library at Oxford, vol. 2 part 1 (Oxford, 1922), p. 14.
Fol. (iv) verso: an early modern table of contents ('In hoc m.s. continentur...').

listBibl.bibl: A. B. Scott, 'The Poems of Hildebert of Le Mans: A New Examination of the Canon', Mediaeval and Renaissance Studies 6 (1968), pp. 42-83 at p. 49.
A. G. Rigg, 'Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (IV)', Medieval Studies 43 (1981), pp. 472-497, at p. 477.
A. G. Rigg, A History of Anglo-latin Literature (Cambridge, 1992), pp. 150-151.
Thomas Hayes, Das Lateinische Lehrgedicht im Mittelalter (Leiden, New York, Köln, 1997), pp. 274-275 and 320-321.

msItem.title: Song of Songs
msItem.incipit: Osculetur me osculo oris sui
msItem.explicit: ceruorum super montes aromatum.

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: Meditatio I
msItem.incipit: Terret me uita mea
msItem.explicit: Qui cum deo patre et spiritu sancto gloriaris per interminata secula. Amen.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: ed. Franciscus S. Schmitt, Sancti Anselmi Opera, 6 vols. (Edinburgh, 1946–61), 3:3, 76-79.

msItem.author: Martin of Braga
msItem.title: Formula uitae honestae (extract)
msItem.incipit: Quatuor uirtutum species multorum sapientum sentenciis diffinite sunt
msItem.explicit: animo tuo cuncta propone.
msItem.note: The extract includes sections 1a - 2 (line 21) in Laura Ranero Riestra's edition.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Laura Ranero Riestra (ed. trad.), La Formvla vitae honestae de Martín de Braga y el Libro de las cuatro virtudes de Alfonso de Cartagena (Pisa, 2021), which lists previous editions. The manuscript is listed (no. 67), but the extract of the Formula uitae honestae at ff. 15r-16r is not identified (only the extract beginning at fol. 58v is identified).

msItem.title: Text on Ps. 83,5 (Beati qui habitant in domo tua domine)
msItem.incipit: Beati qui habitant in domo tua domine
msItem.explicit: labore qui autem presentem

msItem.author: Melito, Saint, Bishop of Sardis
msItem.title: Transitus Mariae, version B2
msItem.rubric: Incipit narracio de assumpcione beate uirginis marie.
msItem.incipit: Sanctus mellito de assumpcione gloriose dei genitricis que a beato (prologue)
Melito seruus Christi ecclesie sardiensis (text)
msItem.explicit: pariter in triumpho. Qui vivit et regnat in secula seculorum. Amen.

listBibl.bibl: Text edited in Monika Haibach-Reinisch, Ein neuer 'Transitus Mariae' des Pseudo-Melito (Rome, 1962), pp. 63-87. Manuscript O1.

msItem.title: Text on the Virgin Mary
msItem.note: The text (with minor variants) is found in Pietro di Ripalta's Chronica placentina.
msItem.incipit: Beata uirgo Maria mater Domini duodecim annorum fuit quando per Spiritum Sanctum angelo nuntiante concepit...
msItem.explicit: Uixit autem beata uirgo Maria annis xx in domo beati

listBibl.bibl: Printed in Pietro da Ripalta, Chronica placentina nella trascrizione di Iacopo Mori (Ms. Pallastrelli 6), ed. M Fillìa and C. Binello (Piacenza, 1995), pp. 33-34.

msItem.note: Fol. 26 is blank, save for a later addition in an early modern hand (a reference to the 1555 Basel edition of Marbod of Rennes' Liber lapidum, a copy of which is found at fol. 27r).

layoutDesc.layout: Quires 1 and 2: 1 col., 17 lines, double vertical bounding lines on each side of the text. c. 83 5 + 55 + 5 Ruled in leadpoint, written above top line.
Quire 3: 1 col., 22 lines, Single vertical bounding lines. c. 85 × 60 mm. Ruled in leadpoint, written above top line.

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 10r-16v: Additions in several early Gothic hands, sometimes irregular, with elements of documentary handwriting.
Fols. 17r-20v: An irregular Gothic bookhand executed with a thick nib. A few elongated descenders on the final lines of pages.
Fol. 25v: An addition in an informal Gothic hand. A blank space is left at the beginning of the text for a painted initial, which was not inserted ('[B]eata').

decoDesc.decoNote: Four-line painted green and red 'arabesque' initial at fol. 1r (Pächt and Alexander, vol. 3, p. 15, no. 125).
Red initials with green penwork, fols. 10r, 16v.
Blue, green or red initials with penwork in red or blue (fols. 17r-20r).

history.origin: 12th century, first half; additions, 13th century, early (fols. 10v-16v), and 13th century, middle (fols. 17r-25v)England (?)

msItem.author: Marbode, Bishop of Rennes
msItem.title: Liber lapidum
msItem.rubric: Incipit libellus de nominibus et naturis et locis lapidum
msItem.incipit: Euax rex arabum
msItem.explicit: Que decies senis distincta patent capitellis.

msItem.title: Verses on the calendar
msItem.incipit: Sciendum quod prius xvi kalendas februarii
msItem.explicit: in terminus pentecostes.

msItem.title: Verses on the canonical hours
msItem.incipit: Cantatur prima, sumebas Christe flagella
msItem.explicit: In media nocte baratr' spoliauerit ipse

listBibl.bibl: U. Chevalier, Repertorium hymnologicum, vol. III (Louvain, 1904), no. 24248.

msItem.incipit: Anna uiro Iohachim genuit te uirgo maria
msItem.explicit: Sic \tribus/ Anna uiris genuit tres una (sic) Marias.

listBibl.bibl: Printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1423.
U. Chevalier, Repertorium hymnologicum, vol. III (Louvain 1904) no. 23010. See also vol. I, no. 1113 ('Anna viro Joachim peperit te virgo Maria').

For a list of manuscripts with the poem beg. 'Anna viro Joachim peperit te virgo Maria': Salome and the kin of Jesus. The treatises of Maurice of Kirkham and Herbert of Bosham, ed. and trans. C. J. Mews et al. (Toronto, 2024), p. 190.
A variant of WIC 1067 ('Anna viro Joachim peperit te virgo Maria').

msItem.title: Text on the figures of speech and tropes
msItem.incipit: Est barbarismus uerbi corruptio uilis
msItem.explicit: Antismos lepide subsannat sed sine felle
msItem.note: A further line of text was added after four blank lines: 'Per casus uariat uerbum, polinthethon unde'.

msItem.author: Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours (attrib.)
msItem.title: De malicia saeculi siue De peccato originali
msItem.incipit: Tot scelerum morbis totus prope subiacet orbis
msItem.explicit: Falsa que iustificat, iustaque falsificat.
msItem.note: Only the first 22 verses are included.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in Hauréau, Les mélanges poétiques d'Hildebert de Lavardin (Paris, 1882), p. 337.
U. Chevalier, Repertorium hymnologicum, vol. IV (Louvain, 1912), no. 41266.
R. Newhauser, I. Bejczy, A Supplement to Morton W. Bloomfield et al., 'Incipits of Latin Works on the Virtues and Vices, 1100-1500 A.D.' (Turnhout, 2008), no. 6025.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 20-1 lines; ruled in lead point, written above top line. Visible pricking in inner margin (quire 4) and outer margin (quire 7). Irregular ruling pattern (with double vertical bounding lines on the left and a single bounding line on the right or no bounding line on the right or, in some cases, double vertical bounding lines on both sides of the text). c. 90 6 + 49 (fol. 27r).

handDesc.handNote: Early Gothic hands, sometimes irregular, with varying degrees of documentary influence, such as elongated ascenders and descenders, or the stylised treatment below the baseline of the letters 'f', 'q' and 's', and sometimes 'r'. Additions at fol. 54v.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red initials with green or red penwork (the penwork may be a later addition). Some guide letters.

msItem.author: Martin of Braga
msItem.title: Formula uitae honestae (extract)
msItem.rubric: Incipit libellus Martini episcopi ad Milonem regem Gallicie. De quatuor uirtutibus cardinalibus
msItem.incipit: Quatuor uirtutum species multorum sapiencium sentenciis diffinite sunt
msItem.explicit: deficientem contempnat ingnauiam.

listBibl.bibl: Text edited in: Laura Ranero Riestra (ed. trad.), La Formvla vitae honestae de Martín de Braga y el Libro de las cuatro virtudes de Alfonso de Cartagena (Pisa, 2021), which lists previous editions. The manuscript is listed (no. 67).

msItem.note: Folios 67-69 (the end of the eighth quire) are blank.

extent.note: Signs of trimming on top and outer edges.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 23 lines. Lead point ruling. Visible pricking on outer and lower margins. First line of text below the top line. Double vertical bounding lines on both sides of the text, ruled space c. 73 3 +50 + 3

decoDesc.decoNote: Blue and red painted initials, with alternating red or green penwork. Some guide letters.

msItem.title: Interrogatory for examining conscience, in prose
msItem.rubric: Ici comence le penitencer ... De orguil [party erased]
msItem.incipit: Les especes de orguil...

bibl.ref: JONAS: Répertoire des textes et des manuscrits médiévaux d'oc et d'oïl

listBibl.bibl: R. Dean and M. Boulton, Anglo-Norman Literature. A Guide to Texts and Manuscripts (London, 1999), p. 362, no. 661.

msItem.title: Extracts of patristic texts and commentary
msItem.incipit: De paucitate saluandorum. Bernardus. Ne mireris ut in multitudine uocatorum paucitas inueniatur electorum
msItem.explicit: cum bonis temporalibus replerentur.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 26 lines. Lead point ruling. Visible pricking on outer margin. First line of text above or below the top line. Fol. 70: single vertical bounding lines, c. 77 x 60 mm. Fols. 71-83: double vertical bounding lines on both sids of the text, c. 72 4 + 55 + 3

handDesc.handNote: Fol. 70: a small Gothic bookhand. Fols. 71-83: a small Gothic bookhand. Some of the ascenders on the top lines and descenders on the bottom lines are elongated.

decoDesc.decoNote: Fol. 70: red painted initials, with green penwork.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.note: Part of a collection of prayers at fols. 85r-92v
msItem.incipit: Miserere mei Deus secundum magnam misericordiam tuam
msItem.explicit: Qui in trinitate perfecta uiuis et regnas deus per omnia secula seculorum amen.

msItem.title: Oratio de sancta maria
msItem.note: Part of a collection of prayers at fols. 85r-92v
msItem.incipit: Sancta Maria immaculata uirgo
msItem.explicit: qui es benedictus in secula seculorum amen.

msItem.title: Oratio de domino ihesu christo
msItem.note: Part of a collection of prayers at fols. 85r-92v
msItem.incipit: Domine Ihesu Christe esto michi peccatori
msItem.explicit: te merear semper habere in mente amen.

msItem.title: Oratio ad dominum Ihesum Christum
msItem.note: Part of a collection of prayers at fols. 85r-92v
msItem.incipit: O pietatis dulcedo domine
msItem.explicit: uiuit et regnat in unitate spiritus sancti deus per omnia secula seculorum amen.

msItem.title: Oratio ad dominum Ihesum Christum
msItem.note: Part of a collection of prayers at fols. 85r-92v
msItem.incipit: Adoro te domine Ihesu christe deus eterne
msItem.explicit: per te saluator mundi qui cum deo patre

msItem.title: Oratio ad Sanctam Mariam
msItem.note: Part of a collection of prayers at fols. 85r-92v
msItem.incipit: O beata Dei genitrix Maria
msItem.explicit: peccatorum meorum remissionem merear accipere per eundem.

msItem.note: Part of a collection of prayers at fols. 85r-92v
msItem.incipit: Deus qui nobis signatis lumine uultus
msItem.explicit: ad faciem uenientem super nos iudicem securi uideamus. dominum nostrum ihesum christum filium tuum.
msItem.note: Later medieval notes in lower margin at fol. 91v, now erased.

msItem.title: Oratio ad dominum Ihesum Christum
msItem.note: Part of a collection of prayers at fols. 85r-92v
msItem.incipit: Deus qui pro redemptione humani generis
msItem.explicit: cum deo patre et spiritu sancto uiuit et regnat deus per omnia secula seculorum. Amen.
msItem.note: Later medieval notes added in the blank space at the end of fol. 92v.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 25-6 lines. Lead point ruling. Visible pricking on outer and lower margins. First line of text above or below the top line. Double vertical bounding lines on both sides of the text, with variations. Ruled space c. 78 2 + 52 + 3 (fol. 85r: c. 76 x (2 + 48 + 2)

decoDesc.decoNote: Red and blue painted initials, with green or red penwork.

msItem.title: Epitaphium in mortem Scaeve, Rufini et Aytos
msItem.incipit: Occumbunt fixi iaculo, mucrone, sagitta
msItem.explicit: Ore Rufinus, Athis corpore, Sceua coma.

listBibl.bibl: 16 verses printed in A. Riese, Anthologia latina sive poesis latinae supplementum, I, vol. I (Leipzig, 1869), p. LXIV.

msItem.title: Epigrammata
msItem.incipit: Cum de latrina lapsum Salomona ruina
msItem.explicit: Plaudit et ipse iubet, cras ut ibi recubet.

listBibl.bibl: WIC 3580. See also WIC 4852 ('Dum de latrina lapsum Salomonem ruina').

msItem.title: Rufus and Corinna (poem)
msItem.incipit: Ruffe, doles et flere soles quod pulcra Corinna
msItem.explicit: Negligitur – nec te patitur – tua forma placere.

listBibl.bibl: A. G. Rigg, ‘Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (I)’, Mediaeval Studies 39 (1977), no. 44a, p. 304.

msItem.note: The text is also found in MS Rawl. G. 109. Full transcription of the text in the online description of MS Rawl. G. 109 (no. 49).

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: An doleam flens propter eam uir lumine casse
msItem.explicit: Non potuit, nec digna fuit, iungi meliori.

listBibl.bibl: A. G. Rigg, ‘Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (I)’, Mediaeval Studies 39 (1977), no. 44b, p. 304.

msItem.note: The text is also found in MS Rawl. G. 109. Full transcription of the text in the online description of MS Rawl. G. 109 (no. 49).

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: Est hodie locus inuidie uirtutis egestas
msItem.explicit: Perfidus et nequam rem iustam dampnat et equam.

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: Quam prauus mos est pueros preferre puellis
msItem.explicit: Aut se dampnandos flammis et sulphure discant.

listBibl.bibl: Verses 1-4 printed in E. Dümmler, 'Zur sittengeschichte des mittelalters', Zeitschrift für deutsches Altertum 22 (1878), p. 256.
A 16-verse variant is printed in W. Wattenbach, 'Beschreibung einer Handschrift der Stadtbibliothek zu Reims', Neues Archiv 18 (1893), p. 519.

msItem.title: Planctus Oedipodis
msItem.incipit: Diri patris infausta pignora, ante ortus dampnati tempora
msItem.explicit: Cruciatus est ineffabilis, quem patimur gens miserabilis.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: W. Wattenbach, 'Die Klage des Oedipus', Zeitschrift für deutsches Altertum und deutsche Literatur 19 (1876), pp. 90-92; M. Esposito, 'Analecta varia. Part I', Hermathena 35 (1909), pp. 365-366.

msItem.title: Versus contra feminas
msItem.incipit: Femina sordida, femina perdita, digna cathenis
msItem.explicit: quam mea sumere, uel mea tangere, sustineam te.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De mysterio missae
msItem.rubric: Hildebertus cenomanensis episcopus de canonice misse
msItem.incipit: Scribere proposui que mistica sacra priorum
msItem.explicit: Cum pater ad dextram cedit et explet opus.
msItem.note: The end of the poem is omitted.

msItem.title: De ordine missae
msItem.incipit: Missam beatus Petrus apostolus primum fertur celebrasse Antiochie
msItem.explicit: et ex hoc ad cunctas transiuit ecclesias.
msItem.note: A copy of the text is found in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 265, pp. 440-442. See Michel Andrieu, Les ordines romani du haut moyen age 1 (Louvain, 1931), p. 101.

msItem.title: On the symbolism of mass
msItem.incipit: Prima sacerdotis statio ad dexteram altaris in principio misse significat rectitudinem
msItem.explicit: Christo fideliter iuncti fulgebunt.

msItem.author: Master Walo
msItem.title: Epitaph of William Clito (d. 1128)
msItem.incipit: Mars obit in terris, deflent par sidera sidus
msItem.explicit: Occasus fuit hic sideris ortus ibi
msItem.note: On authorship: Diana Greenway (ed. trad.), Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People (Oxford, 1996), pp. 836-838; Richard Sharpe, A Handlist of the Latin Writers of Great Britain and Ireland before 1540. With Addictions and Corrections (Turnhout, 2001), pp. 156 and 707; George T. Beech, 'A Previously Unknown Loire Valley Monk (Saumur), Poet, and Bishop in Brittany, Galo († 1129)', Francia. Forschungen zur westeuropäischen Geschichte 46 (2019) pp. 49-75, at p. 68, n. 12.

listBibl.bibl: First two verses printed in: J. Werner, Beiträge zur Kunde der lateinischen Literatur des Mittelalters (Aarau, 1905), p. 40, no. 99.

Full poem edited, with comparison of different manuscripts, in: Diana Greenway (ed. trad.), Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People (Oxford, 1996), pp. 836-838.

msItem.title: Epitaph of pope Urban II?
msItem.incipit: Hic iuuenis lux urbis erat, defectus eclipsis
msItem.explicit: Suscipit inter nos nil nisi fama manet.

listBibl.bibl: A longer version of the poem (with two additional verses at the beginning, inc. 'Canonicus, Remensis Odo, quem Cluniacensis') was printed with the works of Orderic Vitalis in PL 188.178. See also PL 151.583.
WIC 8152 ('Hic uiuens sol (lux) orbis erat defunctus eclipsis').
WIC 2368 ('Canonicus Remensis Odo, quem Cluniacensis').

extent.note: Signs of cropping on outer margins.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 27 lines. Lead point ruling. Visible pricking on outer and lower margins. First line of text above the top line. Fols. 94r-108r and 109v: irregular double vertical bounding lines on each side of the text, on most folios. Ruled space c. 86 3 + 48-56 + 2
Fols. 108v-109r: single vertical bounding lines on each side of the text. Ruled space c. 90 69

handDesc.handNote: Early Gothic hands with some elements of documentary handwriting. The descenders of letters on the final lines are often elongated.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red painted initials, with green, red or black penwork (the penwork may be a later addition). Red stroke added to the first letter of each line on most pages.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De plagis Egipti (Carmina minora, no. 34)
msItem.incipit: Prima rubens unda rane tanesque secunda
msItem.explicit: nona tegit solem: primam necat ultima prolem

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 34. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 246.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Cur bono male vel malo bene (Carmina minora, no. 3)
msItem.incipit: Est aliquando bone bene ne grauibus superetur
msItem.explicit: Est male quo redeat, uel ut hic quoque iam patiatur.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 3. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 212.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Ad Petrum (Carmina minora, no. 2)
msItem.incipit: Susceptum semen sex primis, Petre, diebus
msItem.explicit: Effigiat, tempusque sequens augmentat in ortum.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 3. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 212.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De Roma (Carmina minora, no. 36)
msItem.incipit: Par tibi, Roma, nichil cum sis prope tota ruina
msItem.explicit: uel dominis esset turpe carere fede.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 36.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 249.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De ermafrodito (Carmina minora, no. 23)
msItem.incipit: Dum mea me mater grauida gestaret in aluo
msItem.explicit: Uir, mulier, neutrum, flumia, tela, crucem.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 23. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 234.

msItem.title: Epitaph of Abelard
msItem.incipit: Pyeridum ter trina cohors elycone relicto

listBibl.bibl: A. B. Scott, 'The Poems of Hildebert of Le Mans: A New Examination of the Canon', Mediaeval and Renaissance Studies 6 (1968), pp. 42-83 at p. 49.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Ad Hugonem (Carmina minora, no. 8)
msItem.incipit: Si qua mihi scribis, ne cuiquam scripta reuelem
msItem.explicit: Cum relegam, nequeo scire quid ipsa uelint.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 8. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 216.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin (?) (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: Obscuros uersus facis, Hugo, parumque latinus
msItem.explicit: Uel taceas: melius sic recitare soles.

listBibl.bibl: Poem printed in: B. Hauréau, 'Notice sur les mélanges poétiques d'Hildebert de Lavardin', Notices et Extraits 28.2 (1878), p. 392; B. Hauréau, Les mélanges poétiques d'Hildebert de Lavardin (Paris, 1882), pp. 147-148.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Ad S. nepotem (Carmina minora, no. 33)
msItem.incipit: Res male tuta puer, ne te committe quibusdam
msItem.explicit: Mercedem culpe non dolet esse polum.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 33. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 245.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De Milone mercatore (Carmina minora, no. 7)
msItem.incipit: Milo domi non est. peregre Milone profecto
msItem.explicit: Quo fodiatur ager non habet: uxor habet.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 7. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 215.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Ad Milonem (Carmina minora, no. 9)
msItem.incipit: Thura piper uestes argentum pallia uestes
msItem.explicit: Numquam uendentem deserit aut minuit.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 9. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 216.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Unde malum (Carmina minora, no. 5)
msItem.incipit: Qui petis unde malum, cum sint bona cuncta creata?
msItem.explicit: Et per se citius dulcia poma trahunt.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 5. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 214.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De casu huius mundi (Carmina minora, no. 22)
msItem.incipit: Nuper eram locuples, multisque beatus amicis
msItem.explicit: Quicquid uult in me digerat, eius ero.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 22. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 229.

msItem.incipit: Trax puer astricto glacie dum ludit in Hebro
msItem.explicit: Hoc peperi flammis cetera, dixit, aquis.

listBibl.bibl: A variant is printed in A. Riese, Anthologia latina sive poesis latinae supplementum, I (Leipzig, 1869), pp. 159-160, no. 709.

msItem.title: Epitaph of Soranus
msItem.incipit: Ille ego Pannoniis quondam notissimus horis
msItem.explicit: Exemplo mihi sum, primus qui talia gessi.

listBibl.bibl: A. Riese, Anthologia Latina: sive, Poesis Latinae svpplementvm, no. 662.
Poetae latini minores, ed. E. Baehrens (Leipzig, 1878), vol. 4, p. 113.

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: Hec duo carta salus mihi nobis missa fuerunt
msItem.explicit: ecce reportamus, debita quisque sua.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in A. B. Scott, 'Some Poems attributed to Richard of Cluny', Medieval Learning and Literature. Essays presented to Richard William Hunt (Oxford, 1976), pp. 195-199, no. 5.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De quodam servo (Carmina minora, no. 24)
msItem.incipit: Seruus ait Domino 'gratis famulabor in annum
msItem.explicit: Ne messem famuli sic emat ulterius.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 24. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 235.

msItem.incipit: Paruus erat limes quo presbiter ire solebat
msItem.explicit: Hanc fugat hunc iugulat huic pudenda secat.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Quid sit vita pudica (Carmina minora, no. 47)
msItem.incipit: In noctem prandes, un lucem, Turgide, cenas
msItem.explicit: Vis dicam quid sit uita pudica? Modus.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 47. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 275.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De tribus vitiis: mulieri amore, avaritia, ambitione (Carmina minora, no. 50)
msItem.incipit: Plurima cum soleant more euertere sacros
msItem.explicit: Fraude, cruore, dolis, mens, manus, ora uacant.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 50. Manuscript L.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces': The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), pp. 279-282.

msItem.author: Ps.-Ausonius
msItem.title: Septem sapientum sententiae
msItem.incipit: Que nam summa boni? Que mens sibi conscia recti
msItem.explicit: Quid stulti proprium? Non posse et uelle nocere.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in C. Schenkl, MGH Auct. Ant. 5,2, pp. 246-247. See also PL 19.875.
Also printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1410 (Carmina miscellanea, no. 68).
R. Newhauser, I. Bejczy, A Supplement to Morton W. Bloomfield et al., 'Incipits of Latin Works on the Virtues and Vices, 1100-1500 A.D.' (Turnhout, 2008), p. 262, no. 4482.
A. G. Rigg, ‘Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (I)’, Mediaeval Studies 39 (1977), p. 300, no. 22.

msItem.incipit: Cherule, tu cenas apud omnes nullus apud te
msItem.explicit: Dedecus est semper sumere, nilque dare.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: Anexdota Oxoniensia. Texts, documents, and extracts chiefly from the Manuscripts in the Bodleian and other Oxford Libraries, Vol. I, Part V. Collatio cod. Harleiani 2610 Ovidii Metamorphoseon I, II, III. 1-622. Epigrammata latina XXIV ex codicibus Bodleianis et Sangallensibus. Glossae in Apollinarem Sidonium ex codice Digbeiano 172, ed. R. Ellis (Oxford, 1885), p. viii. A four-verse variant is printed in A. Riese, Anthologia latina sive poesis latinae supplementum, I, vol. II (Leipzig, 1906), p. 391.
WIC 2677
D. Schaller and E. Könsgen, Initia carminum latinorum saeculo undecimo antiquiorum (Göttingen 1977), no. 2149.

msItem.incipit: Iuras dasque fidem tibi te nullam sociasse
msItem.explicit: Ergo pudicus eris, Neuole? non sequitur.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Anexdota Oxoniensia. Texts, documents, and extracts chiefly from the Manuscripts in the Bodleian and other Oxford Libraries, Vol. I, Part V. Collatio cod. Harleiani 2610 Ovidii Metamorphoseon I, II, III. 1-622. Epigrammata latina XXIV ex codicibus Bodleianis et Sangallensibus. Glossae in Apollinarem Sidonium ex codice Digbeiano 172, ed. R. Ellis (Oxford, 1885), p. viii.

msItem.author: Martial
msItem.title: Epigrams, I, 97.
msItem.incipit: Cum clamant omnis loqueris tunc, Neuole, tantum
msItem.explicit: ecce, tacent omnes: Neuole, dic aliquid.

listBibl.bibl: WIC 3568
D. Schaller and E. Könsgen, Initia carminum latinorum saeculo undecimo antiquiorum (Göttingen 1977), no. 2990.

msItem.title: Epigram
msItem.incipit: Ut belli sonuere tube, uiolenta peremit
msItem.explicit: Argolicus Teutras, Marsus Clonus, Ybalus Archas.

listBibl.bibl: A. Riese, Anthologia latina sive poesis latinae supplementum, I, vol. II (Leipzig, 1906), p. 306 (no. 392).
D. Schaller and E. Könsgen, Initia carminum latinorum saeculo undecimo antiquiorum (Göttingen 1977), no. 16845.

msItem.note: Further notes in an informal Anglicana hand (s. xiv) in the space left blank at the end of fol. 116v ('Amen dico vobis super omnia bona sua...') and on fol. 117v ('Fuit homo missus a Deo cui nomen').

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 25 lines. Lead point ruling. Visible pricking on outer, lower and top margins. First line of text above the top line. Irregular ruling pattern, with double bounding vertical lines on the right, and sometimes on the left. Ruled space c. 82 5 + 50 + 5 when there are double bounding vertical lines on both sides of the text.

handDesc.handNote: An early Gothic hand, sometimes irregular, with elements of documentary handwriting, such as slightly elongated ascenders. The descenders of letters on the final lines are often elongated.
Fols. 116v and 117v: additions in an informal Anglicana hand.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red painted initials, with red or black penwork (the penwork may be a later addition). Red stroke added to the first letter of each line on most pages.

msItem.incipit: Patrue pene pater, pater esto mihi sine pene.
msItem.explicit: Est et erit, tibi det, quod cupis ipse dari.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in C. Wollin, 'Sine uix und absque fere. Ein Beitrag zum Manierismus in der lateinischen Dichtersprache des 12. Jahrhunderts', Archivum Latinitatis Medii Aevi, tome 72 (2014), pp. 129-186 at p. 185.
WIC 13841. See also WIC 13751 ('Parve pene pater, pater esto mihi sine pene').

msItem.author: Serlo of Bayeux
msItem.title: Defensio pro filiis presbyterorum
msItem.incipit: Rex immortalis, quam longo tempore talis
msItem.explicit: Quoque modo scimus si nota referre uelimus.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Th. Wright, The Anglo-Latin satirical poets and epigrammatists of the twelfth century, vol. 2 (London, 1872), p. 208-212; Böhmer and Dümmler, Libelli de Lite, III (Hannover, 1897), pp. 580-583.
E. Van Houts, 'The Fate of the Priests’ Sons in Normandy with Special Reference to Serlo of Bayeux', The Haskins Society Journal, 25 (2013), pp. 57-106, at p. 83.
E. Van Houts, 'Serlo of Bayeux and England', Tabularia, Autour de Serlon de Bayeux : la poésie normande aux XIe-XIIe siècles (2016)
M.-A. Lucas-Avenel and E. D’Angelo, 'Vers une nouvelle édition des poèmes de Serlon de Bayeux', Tabularia : Sources écrites des mondes normands médiévaux (2017)
E. D’Angelo, 'Enquête sur un poète au-dessus de tout soupçon : la production cachée de Serlon de Bayeux (I)', Revue d’Histoire des Textes, 16 (2021), pp. 241-258.

msItem.incipit: Hunc numerare diem possim meliore lapillo
msItem.explicit: Sic pedis alterius iura terenda dedi.
msItem.note: The text includes extracts of classical poets, such as Ovid, Ars amatoria, I.40.

msItem.incipit: Ad doctoris...
msItem.explicit: Breues cibos, breuis in se, sibi...
msItem.note: The text includes a quote from Horace, Ars poetica (vv. 372-373: 'mediocribus esse poetis / non homines, non dii, non concessere columpne'), and a quote from Walther of Chatillon, Satire against the Curia (ed. F. J. E. Raby, The Oxford Book of Medieval Latin Verse (Oxford, 1959), no. 198, v. 32 ('Ipse licet ueniat musis comitatus, Homerus')).
Fol. 123 is blank and torn. Vertical rubrication at fol. 123r is not legible.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 25 lines. Lead point ruling. Visible pricking on outer and top margins. First line of text above the top line. Irregular ruling pattern, with double bounding vertical lines on the right, and sometimes on the left. Ruled space c. 90 3 + 46-49 +3 (when there are double bounding vertical lines on both sides of the text)

handDesc.handNote: An early Gothic hand, sometimes irregular, with elements of documentary handwriting, such as slightly elongated ascenders. Some of the descenders of letters on the final lines are elongated.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red painted initials, with red or black penwork (the penwork may be a later addition).

msItem.author: Petrus Riga (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: Hactenus arrisit Susanne gratia fame
msItem.explicit: Hec meruit titulos, hii meruere crucem
msItem.note: The final two verses are not included in the printed editions.

listBibl.bibl: Printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1287. Printed in Hauréau, Notices et Extraits 29.2, pp. 352-358 where it is attributed to Peter Riga. Printed in Mozley, 'Susanna and the Elders: Three medieval poems', in: Studi medievali 3 (1930), 27-52 at pp. 36-41 (poem 1a).

msItem.note: According to Beichner, the text belongs to a group of poems composed independently which circulated as part of Peter Riga's Floridus aspectus, and were later incorporated into his Aurora: Aurora: Petri Rigae Biblia versificata, ed. Beichner (Notre Dame, 1965), p. xv.

msItem.title: Poem on England
msItem.incipit: Istic inuenies uenalia tanta quod omnes
msItem.explicit: Terminat hora diem, terminat auctor opus
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning. The final 16 verses of the poem are copied at the top of fol. 130r, and fols 128v-129v were left blank.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: W. Wattenbach, 'Verse aus England', in: Neues Archiv (1876), p. 602 (poem no. III). Only the final 16 verses of the poem printed by Wattenbach are present here.

The 16 verses included here are part of a longer piece, edited in A. B. Scott, 'Some Poems attributed to Richard of Cluny', Medieval Learning and Literature. Essays presented to Richard William Hunt (Oxford, 1976), pp. 195-199. Manuscript La.
See also WIC 8644 ('Ibis et in nostros').

msItem.author: Hugo Primas (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: In cratere meo Thetis est sociata Lyeo
msItem.explicit: Hec duo, propterea sit deus absque dea
msItem.note: Only the first 4 verses are included.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: C. J. McDonough (ed.), The Oxford Poems of Hugh Primas and the Arundel Lyrics (Toronto, 1984), no. 14; Carmina Burana No. 194 (1/3. 28–31) (Manuscript O1).

msItem.note: On attribution, see: A. G. Rigg, ‘Golias and other Pseudonyms’, Studi Medievali (1977), p. 97.

msItem.title: A collection of proverbs extracted from the Ysengrimus
msItem.incipit: Ille, ubi cassa fides, ruit in discrimina casus
msItem.explicit: Plebs procerum cibus est, utpote prata gregum.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: E. Voigt, Ysengrimus (Halle a. S., 1884). Translations include: Nivardus, Ysengrimus. Text with translation, commentary and introduction, Jill Mann (Leiden, 1987); Nivardus, Ysengrimus, Jill Mann, ed. and trans. (Cambridge, Massachusetts, London, 2013); M. Schilling, Ysengrimus : Lateinisch-Deutsch (Berlin, 2020).

msItem.note: A full discussion is in preparation by the cataloguer.

msItem.title: Poem to Saint Anselm? (Quarto Catalogue)
msItem.incipit: Uir felix sanctus virtutis nomine tantus

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: Suspice me miserum...

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: Rex regalis honor laus rerum gloria regum

msItem.title: Verses on London
msItem.incipit: Nobilis, ampla, potens, urbs urbibus anteferenda

msItem.title: Obituary for Queen Matilda, wife of King Henry
msItem.incipit: Prospera non letam fecere nec aspera tristem
msItem.explicit: Raptam perpetuam fecit inesse diem

listBibl.bibl: Poem found in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. D. Greenway, p. 462. See also William Camden, Remaines concerning Britaine (London, 1636), p. 321 (only 4 verses).

msItem.title: Poem on Henry I
msItem.incipit: Henricus regum rex et decus abstulit altos
msItem.explicit: Oraque Francorum mutire superba coegit.

listBibl.bibl: Poem found in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. D. Greenway, p. 464.

msItem.title: Poem on Queen Adeliza
msItem.incipit: Anglorum regina tuos Adeliza decores
msItem.explicit: Nec pudeat dominam lumine clara tuo.

listBibl.bibl: Poem found in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. D. Greenway, p. 468.

msItem.title: Epitaphium Roberti episcopi (epitaph of Robert Bloet, bishop of Lincoln)
msItem.incipit: Pontificum Robertus honor quem fama superstes
msItem.explicit: Liquid, et euigilans uera perhenne uidit.

listBibl.bibl: Poem found in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. D. Greenway, Book vii. 34, p. 470. The epitaph also appears in Book xi. 11, with a variant line 6 (also printed in: T. Wright, The Anglo-Latin Satirical Poets and Epigrammatists of the Twelfth Century 2 (London, 1872), p. 168).

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 23-26 lines. Lead point ruling. First line of text above the top line. Irregular double vertical bounding lines on each side of the text, on most folios. Ruled space c. 80-86 4 + 54 + 3

handDesc.handNote: Several hands. An early Gothic hand, sometimes irregular, with elements of documentary handwriting, such as slightly elongated ascenders. Some of the descenders of letters on the final lines are elongated. Fol. 133r: a feature of style on the ascender of the letter 's' on the top line.
Fol. 133r-v: Additions; an irregular Northern textualis.

decoDesc.decoNote: One red painted initial, with green penwork (fol. 124r) (the penwork may be a later addition).
